https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions: _This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Explore HTML This is a web page written in HTML, the language of the web. You'll learn more about how it works, but first explore it by using the Inspector Tool. # Do This 1. Click on the Inspector Tool . _You will know that the Inspector Tool is on because the button will say "Inspector: On" and lines of code will highlight when hover over content._ 2. Once you turn on the Inspector Tool, you can hover over anything in the preview area and Web Lab will highlight the code that is making that part of the page appear. Notice that some parts of the code have special `< >` markers surrounding the words 3. **With your Navigator:** Use the inspector tool and try to determine which `< >` code create the following effects on the website: - What code makes the text bigger and bolder? - What code makes text appear as a list? - What code makes the text appear on separate lines? - What's a piece of code that doesn't appear to do anything on the screen?

_This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Add Text to the Body When you start any Web Lab project, it will automatically add ``, ``, ``, and `` tags to your project. When you add content to your projects, you'll need to do it between the `` and `` tags because it should be part of the body of your webpage. Another student, Sofia, has already started adding text to her webpage. She started to add paragraph tags so each sentence would appear on its own line, but hasn't finished # Do This 1. Finish adding `

` and `

` tags to Sofia's code so each sentence appears on a separate line 2. Use the Inspector tool to verify that each line appears on its own ::: details [üîé **Show Me How** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

# Use Paragraph Tags The `

` `

` tags or "paragraph" start and end tags are placed around text to indicate that it is part of a paragraph. Placing text between paragraph start and end tags lets the computer know that it should be treated differently, often just spacing it out from other text. # Do This 1. Click in between the `` and `` tags - this is where you'll add your code 2. Create two paragraphs that ask a question and answer it. This can be a trivia question, a riddle, or a joke. - For example: "What continent has the largest land mass?" - "Asia" 3. Place the text you just wrote inside two separate paragraphs by surrounding each line with `

` and `

` tags

One person should add the "fortunately" sentences, and the other person should add the "unfortunately" sentences - Be sure to use `

` and `

` tags so each line of the story appears as a separate line - Repeat this until the story is at least 8 lines long

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions:
# Explore Heading Tags

HTML defines six levels of headings, and these heading elements are H1, H2, H3, H4, H5, and H6. The H1 element is the highest or most important level, and the H6 element is the least important.

These different heading levels help to communicate the organization and hierarchy of the content on a page. For example, headings with an equal or higher ranking indicate the start of a new section, and headings with a lower rank indicate the start of a new subsection that is part of a higher-ranked section.

# Do This

1.  Turn on the Inspector Tool.
2.  Hover over each of the bold headings on the web page to find out which heading size was used.
3.  Discuss with your partner:
    -   When would you use each of these headings?
        -   For example, which heading would you use for a web page title ... when might you use the H6 heading?

# Headings So far, you've organized your content into paragraphs. Another way HTML allows you to organize your code is by using **headings**. A heading is a short piece of text that goes at the top of a section of content, like a title. # Do This: 1. Find the headings in the web page below and use the Inspector Tool to see the code that makes them. 2. Make sure you and your partner agree on what the tags do. 3. Change the code so that "Drawing" and "2 years" match the headings on the rest of the page. ::: details [üîé **Show Me How** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

# Heading Sizes Headings can come in different sizes. In this page, there are six different sized headings, but they are all mixed up. Can you and your partner figure out how to fix them? # Do This: 1. Use the inspector tool to figure out what makes the headings different sizes 2. Make sure you and your partner agree on what the different heading tags do. 3. Change the tags so that the headings are in order from biggest to smallest, and the text says the correct size, as in the picture to the right. ::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions:
# Unordered Lists There are two types of lists in HTML, ordered and unordered lists. An **unordered list** is just a set of _bulleted_ items.

An unordered list element has the tag `
    `. This is an abbreviation for Unordered List. Each item in the list is marked by a list item element `
  • `. This is an abbreviation for List Item. The list item element is a child element, which means that it goes **_inside_** of its parent element, the unordered list (`
      `). Take a look at how the given code below creates an unordered list. Pay special attention to the whitespace and indentation of the `
    • `. # Do This 1. Look at how the `
        ` and `
      • ` tags are used to create an unordered list. 2. Use the `
          ` and `
        • ` tags to create your own dessert list. ::: details [**Show me another example of working code.**]
          Example Result
          • Red
          • Green
          • Blue

          **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::

    • `;. This is an abbreviation for List Item. The list item element is a child element, which means that it goes **_inside_** of its parent element, the ordered list (`
        `). # Do This 1. Use the `

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions:
# Comments HTML comments are an essential aspect of web design and development. They are used to add notes and explanations to your code, making it easier for yourself and others to understand and maintain. By using comments correctly, you can ensure that your code is well-organized and easy to understand, leading to a smoother development process. Adding a comment in HTML is done by using the `` tags. Anything that is placed between these tags **will not be displayed** in the browser, but **will** be visible when looking at the source code. _``_ # Do This 1. Use the comment tag to "comment out" the information _about_ the content. ::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Complete This Level** üîç]

**More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

mini_rubric.rubric_key_concept:
Use HTML to create a web page that includes hierarchical headings, paragraphs, lists, and images.

Understand the need for precision when using computer languages and use appropriate syntax.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_1: All content is contained in tags, uses paragraph tags, multiple sized headings, and at least one list in a logically consistent way. Comments are used to define sections of code.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_2: All content is contained in tags, uses paragraph, heading tags, and a list in a reasonable way.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: Most content is contained in tags.  At least one heading tag is used.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: Little or no content is contained in tags.

CSD Web Headings line break_2024.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to make new lines without starting a new paragraph.  You can use this code to add poems or lists to your page.
CSD Web Headings line break_2024.long_instructions:
# Extra Code: Line Break In some situations, like a poem or a list, you'll want to start a new line inside the same paragraph, like you might do in poetry. You can use the line break `
` tag for this. # Do This 1) Read the HTML and look for where the line break `
` code is used to separate the lines in the poem. 2) Add two more line breaks to separate out the other lines in the poem. **Tip:** The `
` tag is useful for writing addresses or poems. **Note:** Use the `
` tag to enter line breaks, not to separate paragraphs. Always separate each paragraph with its own set of `

` and `

` tags!

CSD Web Headings hr_2024.bubble_choice_description: Learn the code for making a horizontal rule and practice using it.
CSD Web Headings hr_2024.long_instructions:
# Extra Code: Horizontal Rule

In some situations, you'll want to insert a horizontal line, or rule, to break up themes in your page. You can use the horizontal rule `<hr>` tag for this.

# Do This
1) Read the HTML and look for where the `<hr>` code is used to add a horizontal rule in the web page.
2) Add more horizontal rules to break up the page by theme.

CSD Web Headings Special Character 3_202.bubble_choice_description: Learn the code for the special character "&" and practice using it.
CSD Web Headings Special Character 3_202.long_instructions:
# Extra Code: Special Character "&" The ampersand character (**&**) can cause errors in your HTML code because it is actually used for other special characters like less than symbols (**<** is encoded as `<`), and double quotation marks (**"** is encoded as`"`). To use the **&** character in a paragraph correctly, you need the special code `&`. *Yes, you need an ampersand to encode an ampersand!*
In this activity, you'll make up a list some of your favorite things and practice using ampersands. # Do This 1) Read the HTML and look for where the `&` code is used correctly. * Replace the ampersand that is causing pink code with the special code for the symbol. * Fill in the blank categories or add your own using the new code. Try to come up with answers that use the symbol!

CSD Web Headings Free Play_2024.bubble_choice_description: Try using the new code you have learned to create your own HTML page about your favorite books.
CSD Web Headings Free Play_2024.long_instructions:
# Your Favorite Books

Now that you have learned how to create HTML headings, lists, and code special characters, you can put your skills to the test! 

# Do This
1) Create a web page about your favorite books!
	- For example, this web page could include information about your favorite genre of books and then a list of your top 3 favorites!
    - You could even do favorite books and use the horizontal rule tag to separate the descriptions of each one!
    
You may not be able to create the "perfect" web page just yet, but you can develop a **prototype** that shows your general idea!
CSD Web Headings Free Play_2024.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a web page based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their web page, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a web page based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their web page, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

# Add HTML

Next, you should add the HTML to your page.

CSD U2 text style font family_2024.teacher_markdown:
## Note on fonts and font families

For a web browser to display a font, the font **must** be available on the device the web browser is running on.  There's no guarantee that any device has a particular font, so it's much safer to use font **families**, which allow for many different fonts that have the same general look at feel.

If students want to specify an exact font, they'll need to use a font from the web, so the browser can download that specific font to use when rendering the page.  More information on these fonts can be found at [Google Fonts](https://fonts.google.com/) and [W3Schools](https://www.w3schools.com/Css/css3_fonts.asp).

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions:
# Explore Image Tags

Adding images to our web pages is a powerful skill that will make your pages more appealing to users!

An image tag consist of some new components, namely the **src** attribute and the **alt** attribute.

The **src** attribute stands for "source" and the value of this attribute will be the name of the image file you want on your web page.

The **alt** attribute stands for "alternate text" and the value should be a short descriptive word or two about the image. If an image does not load on a web page, it is this alternate text that will show up instead.

# Do This

1.  Turn on the Inspector Tool.
2.  Hover over the image on the web page to find the tag used.
3.  Discuss with your partner:
    -   How do you think they knew what the name of the image should be for the **src** (source) attribute? Where did they find this information here in Web Lab?
    -   What did they put as the alternate text? Do you think that is descriptive enough?
    -   What else do you notice about the image tag?

Add information about where the image came from and its license. *(This image was found at pixabay and was uploaded by the user "Alexas\_Fotos", who used a "free for commercial use" and "no attribution required" license.)* ::: details [üîé **Show Me How** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions:
# The Details Matter

The `src` attribute needs to point to the _exact_ filename of the image you want to use. That means you need to pay attention to spelling, capitalization, and the file extension. Each of the three images on this page is broken because of an improper `src` attribute. 

# Do This

1.  Using the file menu for reference, fix each of the image tags.
2.  When you are finished, each image should display correctly in the webpage preview.

_Note: Even though the images are not loading properly, our website is still showing descriptive text of what should be there because we used `alt` attributes. Cool!_

# Choosing a Good Name It's important for images to have good names, ones that are easy to understand and use characters that are good for links. This project's image names have some problems. # Do This 1. For each image, fix the name according to the following rules: - Avoid special characters such as `&`, `?`, `%`, `/`, `(`, etc. - Make sure the name has a specific meaning that helps you know what the image is. - Use dashes (`-`) or underscores (`_`) instead of spaces. - Keep the names as short as possible and still have a clear meaning. 2. Choose your favorite image and add it to the web page. - Don't forget the attribution! | Image | Amphibian | Attribution | | ----- | ------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | [][0] | ¬† ¬†**kani bushfrog**¬† ¬† | Rison Thumboor - Wikimedia Commons - CC-BY-SA | | [][1] | ¬† ¬†**paedophryne amauensis**¬† ¬† | Rittmeyer EN, Allison A, Gr√ºndler MC, Thompson DK, Austin CC - Wikimedia Commons - CC-BY | | [][2] | ¬† ¬†**red eyed tree frog**¬† ¬† | Carey James Balboa - Wikimedia Commons - Public Domain | | [][3] | ¬† ¬†**fire salamander**¬† ¬† | Cristo Vlahos - Wikimedia Commons - CC-BY | | [][4] | ¬† ¬†**axolotl**¬† ¬† | th1098 - Wikimedia Commons - CC-BY-SA |

::: details [üîé **Show Me How** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][5]

# Uploading Images You can upload images that you've found elsewhere using the **Add Image** button. Go find an image of a different type of pet that you like and download it to your computer (using right-click "Save As"). Once you have your images, click [][0] and upload the image from your computer into your project, where you can then use it in your page. # Do This 1. Find an image you are allowed to use and upload it to this project. 2. Make sure the file name follows your naming rules. 3. Use the `` tag to display the image(s) in your website. - Make sure to add an `alt` attribute! 4. Add the attribution information below the image. ::: details [üîé **Show Me How to Upload** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][1]
https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.teacher_markdown:
# Recommended Search Engines

Because we can't know which sites might be blocked in your district, we've avoided pointing students to a specific search engine. Not all search engines make it easy to set Creative Commons filters - some of the easiest include:

-   [Creative Commons Search][0]
-   [Google Image Advanced Search][1]
-   [Wikimedia Commons][2]
-   [Flickr Creative Commons][3]

As with any site with crowdsourced content, search engine results will change from day to day, and some of those results may be inappropriate for the classroom.  You may want to check these sites shortly before displaying them to the class, and decide what is best for your classroom.

CSD U2 Image Tag Height Width Attributes.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to customize the height and width of images.
CSD U2 Image Tag Height Width Attributes.long_instructions:
# Height and Width Attributes

Images are not always the right size for a webpage. Luckily, there are width and height properties in CSS to set how many pixels tall or wide we want an image to be. _Make sure you **don't set both** "width" and "height" or you may distort the image._

# Do This
1) Find the rule set for the image tags in the CSS file.
2) Add the width property with a value of your choice to make the other images smaller.
   - Example: `width: 300px;`

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions:
# Layout and Style

# Do This

1.  Look through web page below for new styles.
2.  Open the style sheet
3.  With your partner, discuss which parts of the CSS code you think are making the page appear different.
    -   What makes the entire page blue?
    -   How are the images positioned to the left of all the other elements?

In the next few levels, you'll be changing and adding new styles on this page.

# Background Color # Do This 1. Find the code in the style sheet that is making the background of the entire page light blue. 2. Change the code to make the page a different color. 3. Try to change the background color of just the paragraphs. ::: details [üîé **Show Me How** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

# The Body Element

# Do This

1.  Find the `body` rule-set in the style sheet.
2.  Discuss with a partner what you think will happen if you add `text-align`, `color`, or other text properties to the `body` rule set.
3.  Try out some different properties to check your guesses.

# Float

# Do This

1.  Look at the `float` property inside your `img` rule-set
2.  Discuss with your partner what you think the property does.
3.  Change the value from `left` to `right`.

# Width and Height

# Do This

1.  Find the property in the style sheet that controls the width of the images.
2.  Change the width of the images to be larger or smaller.
3.  Create a new rule with a `height` property to control the height of the images.
4.  Use the `width` property in the `p` rule-set to change the width of your paragraphs.

CSD U2 layout style border_2024.bubble_choice_description: Create borders around the elements on your page.
CSD U2 layout style border_2024.long_instructions:
::: details [**What colors can I use in CSS?**] CSS includes most common color names (red, blue, green, etc.), and many uncommon ones. You can see a full list of CSS color names at W3Schools - HTML Color Names. You can still use colors that are not included in the named list, but you will need to use their RGB values. You can read more about using colors in CSS at W3Schools - CSS Legal Color Values ::: ::: details [**How does the code work?**] Here is the code that is making the image borders: ``` img { border-color: saddlebrown; border-width: 4px; border-style: solid; border-radius: 10px; } ``` * `img` is the _selector_. It specifies which elements will have to follow the rules inside the curly braces, in this case, the images. * `border-color: saddlebrown;`,`border-width: 4px;`,`border-style: solid;`, and `border-radius: 10px;` are the rules that make the border. ::: ::: details [**What does the `border-style` property do?**] The `border-style` property determines what kind of border (solid, dotted, etc.) the element has. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS border-style Property ::: ::: details [**What does the `border-radius` property do?**] The `border-radius` property determines the radius of the curves at the corners of the element. A bigger radius makes a bigger, softer curve, and a smaller radius makes a smaller, sharper curve. A radius of zero makes a regular corner. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS3 border-radius property ::: ::: details [**What does the `float` property do?**] The `float` property makes an element "float", meaning that the elements that come after it all flow around it. If the `float` value is `left`, the element will float to the left, and the elements after it will show up on its right. If the `float` value is `right`, the element will float to the right, and the elements after it will show up on its left. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS float Property :::
# Borders * Find the rules in the style sheet that set image borders color and width. * Change the color and width of your borders. * Try out some different border styles. * Choose from `dotted`, `dashed`, `solid`, and `double` * Put a border on another type of page element, such as one of the headings or the paragraphs.

CSD U2 layout style borderradius_2024.bubble_choice_description: Make the corners of your images rounded.
CSD U2 layout style borderradius_2024.long_instructions:
::: details [**How does the code work?**] Here is the code that is making the image borders: ``` img { border-color: saddlebrown; border-width: 4px; border-style: solid; border-radius: 10px; } ``` * `img` is the _selector_. It specifies which elements will have to follow the rules inside the curly braces, in this case, the images. * `border-color: saddlebrown;`,`border-width: 4px;`,`border-style: solid;`, and `border-radius: 10px;` are the rules that make the border. ::: ::: details [**What does the `border-style` property do?**] The `border-style` property determines what kind of border (solid, dotted, etc.) the element has. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS border-style Property ::: ::: details [**What does the `border-radius` property do?**] The `border-radius` property determines the radius of the curves at the corners of the element. A bigger radius makes a bigger, softer curve, and a smaller radius makes a smaller, sharper curve. A radius of zero makes a regular corner. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS3 border-radius property ::: ::: details [**What does the `float` property do?**] The `float` property makes an element "float", meaning that the elements that come after it all flow around it. If the `float` value is `left`, the element will float to the left, and the elements after it will show up on its right. If the `float` value is `right`, the element will float to the right, and the elements after it will show up on its left. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS float Property :::
# Border Radius * Look at the `border-radius` property inside your `img` rule-set * Discuss with your partner what you think the property does. * Try different values for border radius and decide which one you like the best.

CSD U2 layout style margin_2024.bubble_choice_description: Control the amount of space around each element in your page.
CSD U2 layout style margin_2024.long_instructions:
::: details [**How does the code work?**] Here is the code that is putting extra space around the images: img { margin: 10px; } * `img` is the _selector_. It specifies which elements will have to follow the rules inside the curly braces, in this case, the images. * `margin: 10px;` is the rule that puts 10 pixels of space around the image. ::: ::: details [**What does the `margin` property do?**] The `margin` property determines how much space will be around the image. Most of the time, you will define in the margin in pixels. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS margin Property ::: ::: details [**What does `px` mean / What is a pixel?**] Pixel, which is abbreviated `px`, is how elements are measured in CSS. It‚Äôs the size of a single point of light on the screen. :::
# Margin Margins specify how much space should be around an element. * Find the `margin` property in the `img` rule-set. * Change the margin to be larger, and discuss the effect with a partner. * Choose another element type and give it a margin, too.

   - paragraphs
   - lists
   - images

   - background color
   - font color
   - font family
   - font size

   - text alignment
   - text decoration
   - letter spacing
   - text shadow
   - image size
   - border style
   - border radius
   - border color
   - margin

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions:
# Div + Flex

The HTML division tag, called "div" for short, is a special element that lets you group similar sets of content together on a web page inside a container. It is a multi-purpose tag that you can use to do several things including helping with web layouts and CSS. Ultimately, you'll almost always use it to style whatever it contains.

Flexbox gives us a more efficient way to align and distribute space among items in a `div` container, even when their size is unknown and/or dynamic (thus the word "flex"). 

## Do This

1.  Take a look at the web page below and notice the `div` container around the images.
2.  Go look at the CSS file and notice the flex properites applied to the `div`.
3.  Discuss with your neighbor: What do you think each of the properties applied to the `div` tag does to the webpage layout?
    -   Try using the CSS comment out code `/*   */` to comment out one line at a time to see what happens to the layout.
        -   **For example:**
            -   _Add CSS comments to the first property which will look like this: `/* display: flex; */`_
            -   _Then delete those comments and add CSS comments to the next line:  `/* flex-direction: row-reverse; */`_
            -   _Then delete those comments and continue adding CSS comments to each line, one at a time._

# Display, Direction and Wrap The first three steps we typically follow when applying Flex properties are: 1) establish the layout, 2) define the flow direction and if items should wrap, and 3) define how the items should be distributed. Let's try out the **first two steps**: **1) establish flex layout** and **2) define the direction and wrap**. # Do This 1. Add a `div` container around the image tags. 2. Add the class name `.container` to the `div` tag. 3. Add the following Flex properties to the container: - Establish flex layout with `display: flex;` - Define the flow direction with `flex-direction: row;`. - Define if items should wrap with `flex-wrap: wrap;`. 4. Change the size of your Preview window to see the wrapping effects (see gif below). 5. Change the values for the `flex-direction` property to see what each one does: - Value options include: - `row` - `row-reverse` - `column` - `column-reverse` 6. Change the values for the `flex-wrap` property to see what each one does: - Value options include: - `wrap` - `nowrap` - `wrap-reverse`
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Complete This Level** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
::: details [**Show Me How To Resize The Preview Window**] :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Cheat Sheet when needed!** [][0]

# Justify-content After we enable flex for container items, define the flow direction and whether items should wrap or not, the next step is to define how the items in the container should be distributed **horizontally** across the container. We will do this with the `justify-content`property. This property has 6 value options. Assign each one to make the page look like the image to the right. # Do This 1. Add the `justify-content` property to each of the 6 `div` container rules in the stylesheet. 2. Match the image on the right by applying the correct value with each of the `justify-content` properties. Value options include: - `flex-start;` - `flex-end;` - `center;` - `space-between;` - `space-around;` - `space-evenly;` _**Note:** The exact spacing around and between the boxes may be slightly different depending on the size of your results window._
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Cheat Sheet when needed!** [][0]

# Align-items After we go through our first 3 steps of enabling flex, defining the flow direction, whether items should wrap or not, and defining how the items should be distributed **horizontally**, we have the option of defining how the items should be distributed in the container **vertically**. We can do this with the `align-items` property. This property has 5 value options. Your job is to add the `align-items` property to each container and decide which of the five values to use for each container to make the page look like the image to the right. # Do This 1. Add the `align-items` property for each of the 5 `div` container rules in the stylesheet. 2. Match the image on the right by applying the correct value with each of the `align-items` properties. Value options include: - `flex-start;` - `flex-end;` - `center;` - `baseline;` - `stretch;`
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Cheat Sheet when needed!** [][0] [][1]

# Align-content You can use `align-content` to set how **multiple lines** of items are spaced apart from each other. This property determines the spacing _between_ lines and **only has an affect when there is more than one line** of content. Since this property _only has an effect when you have more than one line of content_, it should only be used when you have more than one line of content that is _set to wrap_. Make sure your "Preview" window is resized so that there are two lines of content as the image shows. This property has 6 value options. Assign each one to make the page look like the image to the right. _**Note: the default appearance for all images before adding the `align-content` property is to be stretched to fill the container.**_ # Do This 1. Add the `align-content` property to each of the 6 div container rules in the stylesheet. 2. Match the image on the right by applying the correct value with each of the align-items properties. Value options include: - `flex-start;` - `flex-end;` - `center;` - `space-between;` - `space-around;` - `stretch;`
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Cheat Sheet when needed!**

dsls.description: Try out what you've learned on one or more of the following activities.

CSD U2L12 Div Flex SB_5.bubble_choice_description: Practice horizontal and vertical alignment for columns!
CSD U2L12 Div Flex SB_5.long_instructions:
# Inversed Properties? A really interesting thing happens when we define our `flex-direction` to be in **columns** ... the `justify-content` and `align-items` **switch!!** This means that if we have columns, we'll use `align-items` (or `align-content` if there's more than one line) to determine alignment **across** the container and `justify-content` will determine alignment **vertically**. **You might want to make note of this on your Flexbox Cheat Sheet!** All containers have flex established and `flex-direction: column` property already defined. _When in columns, before the "align" and "justify" have been defined, the default horizontal alignment is "stretch" and the default vertical alignment is at the top of the container._ # Do This 1. Add the `align-items` property with the correct value to horizontally align the images in each container to look like the picture to the right. 2. Add the `justify-content` property with the correct value to vertically align the images in each container to look like the picture to the right.
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::

Examine the image to the right to figure out which containers should get which horizontal and vertical alignment properties. 2. Add the correct properties and values to each container's ruleset in the CSS file. - As before, you may need to resize your "Preview" window to determine if you've matched the image.
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::

CSD U2L12 Div Flex SB_10.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to use a shorthand property to set the  direction and wrap in one line
CSD U2L12 Div Flex SB_10.long_instructions: # Flex-flow `flex-flow` is shorthand for the `flex-direction` and `flex-wrap` properties, which together define the flex container's set up. The default value is `flex-flow: row nowrap;` which establishes the direction as "row" and the wrap as "no wrap". See if you can use this new shorthand property to match the image on the right. The first container has been styled for you with `flex-flow: column wrap;`. _Don't forget that when you use column for the direction, the horizontal and vertical alignment properties switch!_ # Do This 1. Give each container the `flex-flow` property and appropriate values according to the image. 2. Define the horizontal alignment for each container to match the image to the right. 3. Define the vertical alignment for each container to match the image to the right.

CSD U2L12 Div Flex CH_2.bubble_choice_description: Learn a new property to control the spacing between rows and columns
CSD U2L12 Div Flex CH_2.long_instructions: # Row & Column "Gap" The **gap property** explicitly controls the space **between** flex items. It applies that spacing _only between items_ not on the outer edges. The behavior could be thought of as a _minimum space_. If the space is bigger somehow (if you had `justify-content: space-between;` for example) then the gap will only take effect if that space would end up smaller. `grid-gap` accepts one or two values: * A single value sets both `grid-row-gap` and `column-gap` by the same value - _See the spacing between the rows and columns of the items in the first, purple container to the right._ * When two values are used, the first sets the `grid-row-gap` and the second sets the `column-gap` - _See the different spacing between the rows and columns of the items in the second, teal container to the right._ # Do This 1. Assign the gap property to each container in the CSS to match the spacing of the items in the image to the right. - Give the 1st container the `grid-gap` property and define both the row and column spacing to be 50px. - Give the 2nd container the `grid-gap` property and define the spacing to be 10px between the rows and 50px between the columns. - Give the 3rd container the `grid-gap` property and define the spacing to be 50px between the rows and 10px between the columns. - Give the 4th container the `grid-row-gap` property and define the spacing between the rows to be 60px. - Give the 5th container the `column-gap` property and define the spacing between the columns to be 60px. - Give the 6th container the `grid-gap` property and define the spacing between rows to be 25px and spacing between columns to be 70px. ![]()

CSD U2L12 Div Flex CH_1.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to style an element within a container differently than the rest!
CSD U2L12 Div Flex CH_1.long_instructions:
# Child Selector The "child selector" selects all elements that are the "children" of a specified element. ::: details [üîé**Click Here For a Visual of the "Parent"/"Child" Relationship**]
:::
To style child elements you will use the `>` character in the selector of the rule, like this: ``` div > p { font-family: serif; } ``` # Do This ::: details [‚úîÔ∏è **FIRST, EXPAND ME TO SEE HOW THE CHILD SELECTOR WORKS!** ‚úîÔ∏è]
**In the HTML file:** Find the `div` class with the "parent" class attribute in the HTML. - Notice how paragraphs 1, 2, and 4 are direct children within the container - Notice how paragraph 3 is inside the container **but** in its _own_ container. This makes paragraph 3 a "descendant" of the parent container but _not_ a _direct child_. - Notice how paragraphs 5 & 6 are not in the container at all. **In the CSS file:** Find the rule for the paragraph tags that are children of the parent container in the CSS file. - The rule looks like this: **In the Preview Window:** Notice how only the paragraphs that are children of the parent container are getting the yellow background color! :::
**YOUR TURN!** 1. Add a rule to the CSS file that uses the child selector to style the images within the container. 2. Give those images the following properties: - Width of 75px - Solid border style - 30px margin ::: details [üí™üèΩ **Extra Challenge!**] Can you figure out how to use the child selector to style just the _first two images in the container_? - Give those two images the following properties: - Yellow border color - 25px border radius :::

CSD U2L12 Div Flex CH_3.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to style the same type of elements within a container even if they aren't "direct children"!
CSD U2L12 Div Flex CH_3.long_instructions:
# Descendant Selector If you did the previous challenge level you learned what an HTML "child" is and a "child selector" does. _If you did not do the previous challenge level, consider completing it and then coming back to this level. You can also read the documentation on "CSS Selectors" in the **Help and Tips** tab_.
The ability to select child elements in a parent is awesome, but what if you want to select **all** the same type of elements within a **parent**, even if it's **not a direct child**? Easy! We use the **Descendant Selector**!! ::: details [üîé**Click Here For a Visual of the "Parent"/"Child"/"Descendant" Relationship**]
In this example, the descendant selector will style all the paragraph tags in the main, parent container ... even the one that is not a direct child, but a "descendant."
:::
To use a descendant selector, you will format the selector of the rule, like this: ``` div p { font-family: serif; } ``` # Do This ::: details [‚úîÔ∏è **FIRST, EXPAND ME TO SEE HOW THE DESCENDANT SELECTOR WORKS!** ‚úîÔ∏è] **In the HTML file:** Find the `div` class with the "parent" class attribute in the HTML. - Notice how paragraphs 1, 2, and 4 are within the container, while paragraph 3 is a "descendant" of the parent container but not a direct child since it is in its _own_ container, and paragraphs 5 & 6 are not in the container at all. **In the CSS file:** Find the rule for the paragraph tags that are children of the parent container in the CSS file. - The rule looks like this: **In the Preview Window:** Notice how only **ALL** of the paragraphs in the parent container are getting the yellow background color! :::
**YOUR TURN!** 1. Add a rule to the CSS file that uses the descent selector to style **ALL** the images within the container. 2. Give those images the following properties: - Width of 100px - Yellow border color - A margin of 5px ::: details [**EXTRA CHALLENGE**] Add a rule to the CSS file that uses the **child selector** to style just the first two images in the container. - Give those two images the following properties: - width of 115px - Red border color - 15px border radius ::: ![]()

CSD U2L12 Div Flex CH_4.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to create an image gallery with information underneath each image!
CSD U2L12 Div Flex CH_4.long_instructions:
# Image Gallery Cards There are many times when we want to create some sort of image gallery with information about each image underneath. This is easier than it sounds when we use `div` containers, Flex and some CSS styles we already know! Let's see how! # Do This **In the HTML file:** 1) Add a div with a "gallery" class around ALL content after the main page title. 2) Add a child div with a "ramen-card" class around EACH set of image, h3 tag and paragraph. :::details [*Click Me To See What This Code Should Look Like*] ```

``` ::: 3) Add one more child div with a "content" class around EACH set of h3 tag and paragraph. :::details [*Click Me To See What This Code Should Look Like*] ```

``` :::
**In the CSS file:** 1) Add the following styles to the "gallery" rule set: :::details [**Click Me To See The List of "gallery" Class Styles**] - Establish flex layout - Set the flex content to wrap - Define the items to be centered horizontally - Set a margin of 20px to keep the cards from getting too close to each other :::
2) Add the following styles to the "ramen-card" rule set: :::details [**Click Me To See The List of "ramen-card" Class Styles**] - Set the width to 325px - Define the border to be solid, 2px wide, and a color of your choice - Align the text in the center - Set a margin of 10px - Establish flex layout for the content within - Set the layout direction to be in a column - Align the items to be vertically centered :::
3) Add the following style to the "content" rule set: :::details [**Click Me To See The List of "content" Class Styles**] - Set the padding to be 10px :::
4) Add the following style to apply to all **paragraphs within containers the "ramen-card" class**: :::details [**Click Me To See The List of Paragraph Styles**] - Set the font size to be 17px :::
5) Add the following styles to the `h3` headings: :::details [**Click Me To See The List of `h3` Styles**] - Set the bottom margin to be 10px (or less) :::
6) Add the following styles to the images: :::details [**Click Me To See The List of Image Styles**] - Set the width to be 100% :::
**Extra Challenge:** Try playing around with the image style ... can you make the image have a border and spaced within the card to look like the image to the left?

CSD web flex freeplay_2024.bubble_choice_description: Use your new knowledge to add to the web page you started in a previous challenge level
CSD web flex freeplay_2024.long_instructions:
# Add Flex Layout to Your Webpage

Use your new knowledge and skills to add to the page you started in Lesson 6 about something you enjoy! The webpage you created for that lesson in Level 11, challenge f has been transferred below - add Flexbox layouts to your webpage!

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions: # What Do You Notice? What Do You Wonder? Can you spot some **new** stuff going on! # Do This 1. Resize the Preview Window to see items grow and shrink! **In the HTML file:** 1. Take a look at the items in the `div` container. 2. Discuss with your neighbor - What do you notice? What do you wonder? **In the CSS file:** 1. Take a look at the rule sets below the comments that say "CHECK ME OUT!" 2. Discuss with your neighbor - What do you notice? What do you wonder? 3. Find the `width: 10%` property and change it to `30%` - Since `flex-shrink` will only affect items when there is not enough space in the container, this will allow you to see the 5th item shrink to allow room for the other items that are not supposed to shrink. [][0]

# Flex-grow The `flex-grow` property specifies how much a flex item will grow relative to the rest of the flex items. The last item stretches to fill the remaining space. Item 3 below has `flex-grow` set to `5` which means it will grow up to 5 times more than the other items or until the container is filled. # Do This **In the HTML file:** 1. Give the third child item a class attribute of "grow" **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule in the CSS file for the third child item using its class attribute as the selector. 2. Give the third child item a `flex-grow` property with a value of 5. 3. Resize the Preview Window to see the size change accordingly.
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
::: details [**Show Me How To Resize The Preview Window**] :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet when needed!** [][0]

# Flex-shrink The `flex-shrink` property sets the shrink factor for a flex item. This is used when items do not fit inside a container. Just like `flex-grow`, the `flex-shrink` property sets the shrinkage relative to other items. The last item has a `flex-shrink` of 4. This means it will shrink up to 4 times or until the container is filled. # Do This **In the HTML file:** 1. Give the 3rd child item a class attribute of "shrink" **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule in the CSS file for the third child item using its class attribute as the selector. 2. Give the third child item a `flex-shrink` property with a value of 4. 3. Resize the Preview Window to see the size change accordingly.
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
::: details [**Show Me How To Resize The Preview Window**] :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet when needed!** [][0]

# Order Property Since Flex is a layout system that arranges items in rows and columns, the position of each item can be specified with the `order` property. The `order` property sets the item order relative to the other items inside the container. Each items inside the container in the image below has set its own `order`. # Do This **In the HTML file:** 1. Give each child item inside the "flex-order" parent a specific class attribute: - Give the first item the class attribute "item-a" - Give the second item the class attribute "item-b" - Give the third item the class attribute "item-c" - Give the fourth item the class attribute "item-d" **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule in the CSS file for each of the child items using their class attribute as the selector. 2. Set each item's order using the `order` property: - Set the order of "item-a" to be `3` - Set the order of "item-b" to be `2` - Set the order of "item-c" to be `4` - Set the order of "item-d" to be `1`
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet when needed!** [][0]

# Align-self The `align-self` property aligns an item in a flex container. It is important to remember, that this property _overrides_ the container's `align-items` value. The second item in the image below has an `align-self` value of `flex-end`. # Do This **In the HTML file:** 1. Give the second child item inside the "flex-align" parent a class attribute of "align" **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule in the CSS file for the second child item using its class attribute as the selector. 2. Give the item the `align-self` property. 3. Try out the different values: - `flex-end` - `flex-start` - `center` - `stretch` - `baseline` _(you will only see a visual difference with this value if the items have different heights)_
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet when needed!** [][0]

dsls.description: Try out what you've learned on one or more of the following activities.

CSD U2L13 practice_1.bubble_choice_description: Practice setting the `flex-grow` property based on if you want items to grow equally or not!
CSD U2L13 practice_1.long_instructions:
# Grow Based on Container Content! Let's do some more practice with the `flex-grow` property! It turns out, this property can do some cool stuff for our children elements! For example, if we give all child elements a value of `0`, this means that the elements will grow based on the content inside it! So, if one element has more content, it will be larger than the others in the container. Pretty handy! Now, if we want all of our child elements to take an equal portion of the parent container, then we can give all of our children a `flex-grow` value of `1`! Let's give this a try! # Do This **In the CSS file:** 1. Add the `flex-grow` property to the first container and set the child elements grow based on the content inside the container. _See above description to remember what that value should be._ 2. Add the `flex-grow` property to the second container and set the child elements take an equal portion of the parent container. _See above description to remember what the value should be._ **In the HTML file:** 1. Add some more text to **one** of the paragraph in the **"grow0"** container to see the item sizes adjusting based on the content! * _This is the default for all Flex items._
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet when needed!** ![]()

CSD U2L13 practice_2.bubble_choice_description: Practice setting the `align-self` property to create some steps!
CSD U2L13 practice_2.long_instructions:
# Simple Steps We can do some fun stuff without layouts using Flex child properties! Let's practice both the `flex-grow` and `align-self` properties to make us some steps! # Do This **In the HTML file:** 1. Make note of the class attribute names for each of the paragraph tags in the "steps" parent container. **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule to set all child paragraph elements to take up an equal portion of the parent container. - _Hint: you will need to use a child selector. See the "Help & Tips" tab to find out more about child selectors._ 2. Add a rule set for **each** of the paragraph elements to look like steps. - _Hint: you will need to use the `align-self` property for each of the elements._
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet when needed!**

CSD U2L13 practice_3.bubble_choice_description: Practice setting the `order` property to order the steps from practice level b!
CSD U2L13 practice_3.long_instructions:
# Ordered Steps Let's practice ordering our items by changing the order of the steps from the previous practice level b so that they look like the image to the right! _You should make sure you have completed the previous practice level b before completing this practice level._ Don't forget, a value of `0` is the default. Giving a negative value, like `-1` will move the item to the left of the other items and giving a value greater than 0, like `1`, will move the item to the right of the other items. And of course, we can always give our items a specific number value to order our items in the order we want, like `1`, `2`, `3`, etc. # Do This **In the CSS file:** 1. Add the `order` property to each of the paragraph child elements to match the image to the right!
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet when needed!** ![]()

CSD U2L13 practice_4.long_instructions:
# Debug Me! Oh no! Mya was making a page on the Earth's Ecosystems but she can't quite get the images in the right place! Please help her debug the code so that her page matches the one in the image to the right! # Do This 1. Can you find and fix the bugs for each of the image order and alignment layouts in the CSS file to make the page match the image to the right? - _Make sure you view the Preview Window in fullscreen to see if it matches!_
_**Tip:** You might find it helpful to change the `width` of the images to a smaller size while you are debugging so that you can see more images in your Preview Window and see the immediate debugging effects without having to view fullscreen. Just remember to change the `width` back when you find and fix all the bugs!_
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet when needed!**

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions:
# Match The Image Zoie is trying to style her web page to match the layout in the image to the right. Can you help her? # Do This Notice the order, size, alignment, and spacing of the items in the example image. 1. Adjust the order of the items to match the example. 2. Identify any items that are aligned differently from others within the container and apply `align-self` to achieve the same effect. 3. Determine which items need to be larger than others and appy `flex-grow` to thesee items, consider their proportion in the example image. _Make sure you adjust the Preview Window to see if you've matched the image example._
**Don't forget to refer back to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet when needed!** [][0]

dsls.description: Expand your Flexbox skills with these challenges.

CSD U2L13 challenge_1.bubble_choice_description: Learn about another Flex child property that determines the size of your item!
CSD U2L13 challenge_1.long_instructions:
# Flex-basis `flex-basis` is another child Flex property that is used to establish the size of your item. Think of it as the same thing as defining an element's `width`. The default value for this property is `auto` which sets the **ideal size of the element based on its content**. We can also set a specific size for our elements by defining the value of `flex-basis`. # Do This **In the CSS file:** 1. Add the `flex-basis` property to the first container and set value to `auto` - _This will set the "ideal size" of the element based on its content._ 2. Add the `flex-basis` property to the second container and set value to `150px` - _This will explicitly set the size of the element to `150px` **In the HTML file:** 1. Add some more text to **one** of the paragraphs in the **"basis-auto"** container. * Notice how the element will expand as much as it can while still keeping the other two elements at their ideal size based on their content. * _This is the default for all Flex items._ 2. Add some more text to **one** of the paragraphs in the **"basis-fixed"** container. * Notice how the element's width does not change since you set it to be 150px.
**Don't forget to add this property to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet!**

CSD U2L13 challenge_2.bubble_choice_description: "Flex" your skills and learn how to combine `flex-grow`, `flex-shrink`, and `flex-basis` into shorthand!
CSD U2L13 challenge_2.long_instructions:
# Flex Property The "flex" property is the shorthand for `flex-grow`, `flex-shrink` and `flex-basis` combined into one line. When we use it in CSS, it looks like this: ``` div { flex: 1 0 auto; } ``` This example sets the `flex-grow` to 1, the `flex-shrink` to 0, and the `flex-basis` to auto. An easy way to think of this and remember the order is to imagine you are setting the **"max"**, **"min"**, and **"ideal size"**. _Check out the previous challenge level or the "Help & Tips" tab to learn about `flex-basis`!_ Let's check out what some commonly used value combinations for the `flex` property will do! # Do This **In the CSS file:** ::: details [1. Set the child elements of "flex1" to not grow when there is free space, to shrink when there is not enough space, and their size to be based on their content _(expand me to get more instructions)_] - **Add the `flex` property to the "flex1" child elements with the following three values:** - **Set the first "grow" value to 0.** This will make the items _inflexible_ when there is some free space left in the container. - **Set the second "shrink" value to 1.** This will allow the elements to shrink to their minimum size when there is not enough space in the container. - **Set the third "ideal size" value to "auto".** This will size the items based on their content. :::
::: details [2. Set the child elements of "flex2" to grow to absorb any extra space, to shrink when there is not enough space, and their size to be based on their content _(expand me to get more instructions)_] - **Add the `flex` property to the "flex2" child elements with the following three values:** - **Set the first "grow" value to 1.** This will make the items absorb any extra space left in the container. - **Set the second "shrink" value to 1.** This will allow the elements to shrink to their minimum size when there is not enough space in the container. - **Set the third "ideal size" value to "auto".** This will size the items based on their content. :::
::: details [3. Set the child elements of "flex3" to not grow when there is free space, to not shrink when there is not enough space, and their size to be based on their content _(expand me to get more instructions)_] - **Add the `flex` property to the "flex3" child elements with the following three values:** - **Set the first "grow" value to 0.** This will make the items _inflexible_ when there is some free space left in the container. - **Set the second "shrink" value to 0.** This will not allow the elements to shrink even in an overflow situation. - **Set the third "ideal size" value to "auto".** This will size the items based on their content. :::
4. Resize the Preview Window to see the differences between the three layouts. - Make sure you fully expand the Preview Window as well as shrink the window to be very, very small.
**Make sure to add this to your Flexbox Children Cheat Sheet!**

CSD U2L13 challenge_3.bubble_choice_description: Are you ready for the challenge of creating a gallery of images and text?
CSD U2L13 challenge_3.long_instructions:
# Info Card Layout Challenge When we start putting elements into containers within containers and using Flexbox properties and children properties, we unlock the ability to give our web pages some cool layouts! Let's see if we can turn the bottom half of this page into a nice, image and info gallery like the image on the right! # Do This ::: details [**In the HTML file:**] 1. Find the "gallery" container. 2. Add a `div` container around each paragraph in the gallery with the class attribute "info" 3. Add a `div` container around each image in the gallery with the class attribute "image" 4. Add a `div` container around each of the image and paragraph groups with the class attribute "image-card" **_The `div` tags for the first two groups of images and paragraphs have been done for you. Use them as examples for the remaining four groups of images and paragraphs._** :::
::: details [**In the CSS file:**] 1. Establish Flex layout and "wrap" for the "gallery" container. 2. Set the content of the "image-card" to grow at a value of 1 so they all grow at the same rate. 3. Establish Flex layout for the "image-card" so that _its_ child elements can use Flex too 4. Set the "info" container content to align itself to the center. :::
::: details [**EXTRA CHALLENGE**] Can you figure out how to set the order of the "image-card" for the giant squid to be the first image in the gallery, just like the image above? _Hint: You will probably have to give the "image-card" a different class attribute in order to set its order! ü§î Hmmm ... but then how will it continue to have the same properties as the "image-card"?_ ü§î :::
_Make sure you click on the "expand" icon often to see the web page in full screen._
![]()

CSD ch1 project L5 User_2024.bubble_choice_description: Choose this level if you have been building a web page for a user since Lesson 5.
CSD ch1 project L5 User_2024.long_instructions:
# Modify the Web Page Layout

You have been working so hard throughout this chapter to style a web page for a user! Everything looks good except your user has requested some modifications to the layout of the page (_a very common request of web developers_).

Okay web developer ... go tackle this challenge!

# Do This
1) Add needed `div` containers that will allow you to apply Flex layouts as needed.
   - _This may require you to move around some of your HTML content._
2) Add classes as needed to your containers and/or other HTML elements that will require a different style than others of the same type.
3) Add rule sets and properties in your CSS file to modify the layout according to your user's requests.
4) Make sure you use comments and white space to ensure readability. 
5) Double check your user's requests to ensure you have made all requested modifications.

# Making a Multi-page Site

A web site should include more than one web page, and they should connect to each other.   Here's an example of a project with multiple pages that are connected by hyperlinks (the blue underlined words that take you to another page when you click on them).

# Do This

1.  Use the inspector tool to see the code that creates the hyperlinks on the top of index.html.
2.  Discuss with your partner how you think that code works.

# Adding Links This page is almost working, but one of the pages is not linked. # Do This 1. Look at the working links and see how they work. 2. Add code that will link from the index page to the Charles Bridge page. 3. Add code that will link the Charles Bridge page to the index page. ::: details [**Show Me How**]
**More resources in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

# Naming Links

Just like images and files, links should have clear names that help someone understand what page they are linked to.

# Do This

1.  Read the code or click on the links to see where they go.
2.  Change the names of the links to make it clear where they will take you.

# Naming New Pages

You'll need to follow the same rules for naming html pages that you did for naming images.  This page has some problems caused by poorly named HTML files.

# Do This

1.  Click on the links in "index.html" and see which ones are broken.
2.  Change the file names and link `href` attributes so that they follow good naming conventions such as:
    -   Avoid special characters such as `&`, `?`, `%`, `/`, etc.
    -   Make sure the name has a specific meaning that helps you know what the page is
    -   Use dashes (`-`) or underscores (`_`) instead of spaces.
    -   Keep the names as short as possible and still have a clear meaning.
3.  Make sure all link are working with the new file names.
4.  **Bonus:** Add a "Back to home" link to the Scotcharoos page.

You can actually add other tags and content, such as images, to this space in your code as well. # Do this: 1) Look at the code that makes the first two images on the `index.html` page into links. * Use that same code pattern to turn the second two images into links, too.

CSD U2 links buttons_2024.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to style hyperlinks to make them look like buttons
CSD U2 links buttons_2024.long_instructions: # Button Links Take a look at the image below of the five hyperlinks that have been styled to look like buttons. Can you figure out what properties and values you will need to use to make the links look like this? # Do This 1) Find the CSS rule for hyperlinks in your stylesheet. 2) Add the following properties to the hyperlink rule-set with values of your choice: * border-style * border-color * border-radius * padding * text-decoration * *Select "none" for this property* 3) Add the optional properties to the hyperlink rule-set with values of your choice to make the buttons more visually appealing: * background-color * color

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2024/less.long_instructions: # What Do You Notice? What Do You Wonder? There are some cool things happening with our hyperlinks! Can you spot them? # Do This 1. Hover over the hyperlinks in the Preview Window. 2. Click on a hyperlink _very slowly_. 3. Discuss with your neighbor - What do you notice? What do you wonder? **In the CSS file:** 1. Take a look at the rule sets below the comments that say "CHECK ME OUT!" 2. Discuss with your neighbor - What do you notice? What do you wonder? [][0]

# Anchor Tag States An anchor (``) tag has four states: 1. **link**: when the link has not yet been clicked 2. **visited**: when the link has been clicked (clicking a link "visits" that linked page, hence the name "visited") 3. **hover**: when the mouse is hovered over, but not clicked, the link 4. **active**: the moment the mouse is actively clicking down on the link We style these states using pseudo-classes. In the example below, we specify the anchor element selector, a colon, and the name of the anchor state: a:hover { color: yellow; } Let's give the first two states a try! # Do This **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule to style the "link" state of the `` element. - The selector of your rule should look like this: `a:link` - Add the `color` property with a value of your choice. - Add the `font-size` property with the value of your choice. - This will define what your link looks like when it has not been clicked - Add any other properties of your choice.
2. Add a rule to style the "visited" state of the `` element. - The selector of your rule should look like this: `a:visited` - Add the `color` property with a different color than the "link" state. - Add the `font-size` property with a different value than the "link" state. - This will define what your link looks like when it has been clicked - Add any other properties of your choice. **In the Preview Window:** 1. Click on the link. A new tab with "google.com" should open. Come back to Web Lab to see the changes to the look of your link. - _You may need to click the "Refresh and Save" button to see the "visited" style applied to your hyperlink_
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::

# Anchor Tag States - "hover" & "active" We applied two of the four states for the anchor (``) tag in the previous level. Let's try the other two states - "hover" and "active." - **hover**: when the mouse is hovered over, but not clicked, the link - **active**: the moment the mouse is actively clicking down on the link # Do This **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule to style the "hover" state of the `` element. - The selector of your rule should look like this: `a:hover` - Add the `color` property with a dark color value of your choice. - Add the `background-color` property with a bright color value of your choice. - Add the `font-size` property with the value of your choice that is larger than 16px. - **Optional:** Add the `border-radius` property to give the background color rounded edges. - This will define what your link looks like when the mouse is hovering over it - Add any other properties of your choice.
2. Add a rule to style the "active" state of the `` element. - The selector of your rule should look like this: `a:active` - Add the `color` property with a different color than the "hover" state. - Add the `background-color` property with a different color than the "hover" state. - Add the `text-decoration-style` property with a value of your choice. - This will define what your link looks _as it is being clicked_ - Add any other properties of your choice. **In the Preview Window:** 1. Click the "Refresh and Save" button to make sure your styles have been applied. 2. Hover over the link to see your "hover" styling. 3. **_Slowly_** click on the link to see your "active" styling.
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::

# Anchor Pseudo-class Order It is recommended that if you are going to use all four states for an anchor tag, you create your rule sets in CSS in the following order: 1. link 2. visited 3. hover 4. active Setting these out of order on your CSS can create unforeseen actions as the cascading style of CSS can have one property overriding another. In short, if there are competing rule sets, styles declared later typically override those declared earlier. **One way to remember the right order is with the phrase "LOVE, HATE" - LV, HA (Link, Visited, Hover, Active).** # Do This **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule for each of the states for the `` element in the right order. - `a:link` - `a:visited` - `a:hover` - `a:active` 2. Style each state with a different color and font size. 3. Add any other different styles to each state of your choice. **In the Preview Window:** 1. Click the "Refresh and Save" button to make sure your styles have been applied. 2. Test each state to make sure they work - Hover over the link to see your "hover" styling. - _Slowly_ click on the link to see your "active" styling. - Click on the link and come back to Web Lab to see if the link changed to your "visited" style.
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

# Combine Pseudo-class with Classes What if you have more than one hyperlink and you want to style them differently? Normally when we have several of the same element but we want to style one of them differently we would give that element a class attribute. Good news! We can do the same thing with pseudo-classes! To do this, we would use our class attribute in our selector, instead of the anchor tag like this: .special:visited { color: purple; } Let's try it! # Do This **In the HTML file:** 1. Give the first hyperlink a "highlight" class attribute. **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule for the "hover" state of the anchor tag using its "highlight" class attribute in the selector. - `.highlight:hover` 2. Style this state with a different background-color and large font size. 3. Add any other different styles to each state of your choice. **In the Preview Window:** 1. Click the "Refresh and Save" button to make sure your styles have been applied. 2. Hover over the first link to see your "hover" styling. 3. Hover over the second link to confirm it does not have any "hover" styling.
::: details [üîé **Show Me How To Get Started** üîç] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

CSD U2L18 chall_1.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to use the "hover" pseudo-class to hide and reveal text!
CSD U2L18 chall_1.long_instructions:
# Simple Hidden Tip with Hover

Not only can we use the `hover` pseudo-class to draw a user's attention to a hyperlink on our page, but we can also it to **style other elements too**!

Let's see how we can code our CSS to have a "tip" appear when we hover over a `<div>` element.

# Do This

**In the CSS file:**
1. Add the following properties to the paragraph rule set:
   - `display: none;`
   - `background-color: yellow;`
2. Add a rule set to style the paragraph child of the div tag with the "hover" pseudo-class. 
   - Your selector should look like this: `div:hover p`
   - Add the following property: `display: block;`
3. Hover over the `div` to see what happens!

**Don't forget to click "Refresh and Save" to see if everything is working as expected.**

Let's see how we can code our images with the "hover" pseudo-class to bring attention to them. # Do This **In the CSS file:** 1. Add a rule set to style the images with the "hover" pseudo-class. - Add the following properties: - Increased width of the image - "fushia" border color - A defined `border-width` to at least 10px - Add any other properties you think will make the image stand out and bring a user's attention to it! 3. Hover over the the images to see what happens! **Don't forget to click "Refresh and Save" to see if everything is working as expected.**

CSD U2L18 chall_4.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to create responsive image cards!
CSD U2L18 chall_4.long_instructions: # Transforming Image Cards Back in Chapter 1, you learned how to create "product cards" - an image gallery with information about each image underneath. With our "hover" pseudo-class, we can make these cards even more visually appealing and responsive to our users by using two new properties: `transform` and `transition`. The `transform` property applies 2D or 3D transformation to an element. This property allows you to rotate, scale, and move elements! There are _many_ value options! The `transition` property specifies the duration and time for `transform` property. The syntax of this property looks like this: `transition: property duration timing;` _We'll also see how to change our mouse cursor when we hover over an image card using CSS to draw attention to them._ Let's try this out! # Do This **In the CSS file:** 1) Add a rule for the "hover" pseudo-class for the "ramen-card" class. 2) Add the `transform` property with the value of `translateY(-15px)` - _This will set the card to move up by 15 pixels._ 2) Add the `transition` property to the "ramen-card" rule set with a value of `transform 0.3 ease-in-out;` - _This will set the type of transition to "transform" (which we just set in step 2), with a 0.3 duration for the transition, and to ease in and out of the transition._ 4) Add the `cursor` property with a value of `pointer` to the "ramen-card" rule set. **BONUS:** Play around with different `transform` values! Here's a list of some to try: - `translateX(px);` - moves the card left or right depending on if the number px is positive or negative - `translate(x, y);` - moves the card left/right and up/down depending on if the number for eachc px is positive or negative - `scale(x, y);` - resizes the card in both directions. For example, `scale(1.5, 1.5);` will have your card get bigger by 1.5 on both axis. - `scaleX(x);` - resizes the card horizontally - `scaleY(y);` - resizes the card vertically - `rotate(deg);` - rotates the card by the number degrees indicated. Note: the value in the parenthesis should be written as follows: `rotate(20deg);` **HAVE FUN WITH THESE RESPONSIVE TECHNIQUES!**

# Upload Images

Upload all of your team's images into your project.

# Do This

1.  Upload all of the images listed in your team's web site plan into your project.
2.  Double check that each image file name uses good naming conventions.
3.  Double check that everyone on the team has the exact same images with the exact same names.

# Your Group Project

Here is your group project.  It already has an index page, but you'll need to create all of the other pages.

# Do This

1.  Double check all of the page names in your website plan to make sure they follow good naming conventions.
    -   Check with the rest of your group if you need to change a page name.
2.  Create a new page for each of the pages in your website plan.
3.  Inside each new page, create a temporary paragraph tag that describes the page and who is in charge of it.
4.  Check to make sure everyone in your group has the exact same list of HTML pages.

# Add Your Content and HTML

Now add all of the HTML you will need for your project, including links to the stylesheet and other pages.

If you are responsible for the navigation bar, add it here, too.

# Do This

1.  Add HTML to the pages.
2.  Test your links to make sure that they work.
3.  Check that all of your images are displaying.

# Share Your Content and HTML

Share your web page with your teammates, and copy and paste the code for their pages into your project.

# Do This

1.  "Share" your page, and give the link to your teammates.
2.  Get the "Share" link from each of your teammates and click the "View Code" link at the bottom of the screen.
3.  Copy the HTML from your teammates' pages into your project.
4.  Copy and paste the correct navigation bar onto each page.
5.  Check that all of the links and images work correctly.

# Add Your Styles

Now add all of the CSS you are responsible for, including your classes.

# Do This

1.  Add CSS rule sets to the stylesheet.
2.  Check that all of your pages are displaying the correct styles.

# Share Your Styles

Now share all of the CSS styles and classes with your teammates.

# Do This

1.  Use the "Share" link from each of your teammates and click "View Code" to see their HTML and CSS.
2.  Open each of your teammates' stylesheets and copy and paste their code into your stylesheet.
3.  Check the stylesheet to make sure that there are no conflicts (two rule sets for the same tag or style).
4.  Check that all of your pages are displaying the correct styles.

# Check Your Work

Your site is done!  Check to make sure it meets the requirements.

# Do This

1.  Check that your site looks the same as your teammates' sites.
2.  Check that your site includes everything from the project guide.
3.  Check that your site meets the requirements of the project in the rubric.

# Use Feedback

Now it's time to use the peer feedback to make your site even better.

# Do This

1.  Use the plan that your team came up with to improve your website.

CSD U2 FR Q1_2024.long_instructions: What is the purpose of copyright?
CSD U2 FR Q1_2024.teacher_markdown:
**Content: Unit 2 Lesson 8**

Copyright is intended to protect the rights of content creators. These rights include being recognized as the creator when the work is displayed, or deciding who can use and make money off the work.
